Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 44149 
Research and Development Technical Assistance 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Asia Pacific Health Observatory  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since 2008, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the World Bank, and the World Health 
Organization (WHO)1 have been laying the groundwork for creation of an Asia Pacific Health 
Observatory that will collect and analyze information and research evidence on health systems, 
policies and reforms in the region. The European Observatory on Health Systems and Policies 
serves as a model for this initiative.2 The World Bank has shared its experience as a partner of 
the European observatory. WHO’s Western Pacific Regional Office has established a small unit 
and allocated resources to prepare the observatory. ADB has provided small-scale technical 
assistance3 (TA)  to  support  the  publication  of  two  policy  briefs  as  pilot  products  of  the 
observatory, and to organize regional workshops with representatives of ministries of health, the 
research community, and development partners, all of whom are expected to be stakeholders of 
the observatory. 
 
2.  At a stakeholder preparatory workshop held in Bangkok in October 2010, participants 
reached  agreement  on  the  governance  structure  of  the  observatory  and  on  criteria  and 
conditions for membership (including a minimum financial contribution from steering committee 
members).  WHO  has  been  requested  to  finalize  the  legal  documents  necessary  for  the 
establishment of the observatory, which is expected to be formally launched in February 2011. 
The proposed TA will enable ADB to support the observatory.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Health systems everywhere must constantly adapt to evolving conditions. New health 
policies and reforms are regularly needed, for example, because of changes in the burden of 
diseases  and  new  demands  from  the  public  linked  to  economic  development  and  aging 
populations.  While  economic  development  has  enabled  better  control  of  traditional 
communicable diseases, new communicable and noncommunicable diseases are emerging as 
a consequence of people’s mobility, climate change, urbanization, and changing lifestyles. New 
drugs and medical devices improve service quality but also have an impact on the cost of health 
services. Innovative ways of delivering health services can improve cost-efficiency. Government 
restructuring,  such  as  decentralization,  often  requires  redefining  rules  and  regulations  (for 
example,  relations  between  the  center  and  the  regions)  with  an  overarching  objective  to 
maintain service quality and equity in access.  
 
4.   Governments in neighboring countries often face similar issues, and sharing information 
and experiences can help authorities adopt new health policies based on evidence and lessons 
identified. As the European observatory’s experience has shown, two kinds of studies are 
particularly useful: (i) description and analysis of a country’s health system following a template 
that allows comparisons between countries (“descriptions of health systems in transition”); and 
(ii) analysis of selected health policy issues across countries in the region (“policy briefs”).  
 
5.  The objective of the observatory is to present and disseminate information that will help 
governments  adopt  evidence-based  effective  and  efficient  health  policies,  and  to  facilitate 
regional collaboration and integration in Asia and the Pacific. The observatory will produce and 
                                                 
1  Both the Southeast Asia and Western Pacific regional offices of WHO have been involved in discussions on 
creating an Asia Pacific Health Observatory. 
2  The  European  Observatory  was  established  in  1998.  http://www.euro.who.int/en/home/projects/observatory  - 
http://www2.lse.ac.uk/LSEHealthAndSocialCare/LSEHealth/europeanObservatoryOnHealthCareSystems.aspx  
3  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance on Asia Pacific Observatory on Health Systems and Policies. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 December 2010.

2   
disseminate regular descriptions of health systems in transition and policy briefs, involving the 
research community of the region in identifying issues and preparing both types of document. 
By inviting research institutions to join, the observatory will develop an operational research 
network, strengthening research capacity and collaboration in the region. 
 
6.  At the Bangkok workshop, participants5 reached agreement on the observatory’s terms 
of  reference.  It  will  be  a  collaborative  partnership  of  interested  governments,  international 
agencies, foundations, nongovernment organizations, and the research community. A steering 
committee will provide the strategic direction of the observatory, guiding its work and monitoring 
performance. Governments and international agencies that want to be members of the steering 
committee will need to make a minimum annual cash contribution of $100,000.6 Research 
institutions that want to be members of the steering committee will be expected to provide an 
annual in-kind contribution (staff time or facilities) equivalent to $100,000. 
 
7.  The secretariat of the observatory will be located initially in the Western Pacific regional 
office of WHO. WHO will serve as the managing agent of the observatory, bearing responsibility 
for legal and administrative issues. From a legal point of view, the observatory will be a WHO 
program,  and  all  activities  carried  out  by  the  observatory  will  adhere  to  WHO  rules  and 
regulations. Contributions to the observatory (by steering committee members or others) will 
either be pooled or administered separately under a specific agreement between the donor and 
WHO. While the observatory will be legally and administratively a WHO program, the proposed 
governance structure, with a steering committee involving governments, development partners 
and the research community, will make it a dynamic and consultative program. 
 
8.  The observatory will generate and disseminate intelligence on health, identifying gaps 
and good practices in health sectors at both country and regional levels. For example, regional 
collaboration is required to address emerging regional health threats adequately. Preventing 
communicable diseases, which do not respect borders, is a regional public good, that require 
regional  collaboration  including  sharing  of  information  and  coordination  of  responses. 
Infrastructure development, one of ADB core activity areas, facilitates regional integration and 
brings significant economic benefits, but the increased trade and mobility that can result can 
exacerbate regional health threats, such as communicable diseases (severe acute respiratory 
syndrome, avian influenza, HIV/AIDS, and other emerging infectious diseases), food safety 
problems (foodborne diseases and inadequate food quality control), and poor quality or fake 
medicines. These regional health threats can have serious negative impacts on the economy 
and societal well-being. 
 
9.  In response to severe acute respiratory syndrome and avian influenza outbreaks in 
particular, ADB has worked with WHO to stimulate regional coordination and collaboration 
among ministries of health and with other sector ministries. Similar cooperation with the private 
sector  remains  underdeveloped  at  the  regional  level.  The  private  sector,  which  was 
economically affected by the recent health crises in the region, has developed its own expertise 
in risk management and planning for business continuity. A public–private partnership (PPP) for 
regional health security—building on the ADB partnership with WHO for the prevention and 
control of avian influenza, and informed by a dialogue between governments and businesses—
would complement the observatory. Regular consultations with the private sector can improve

health-related  policy  making  and  regional  health  security.  Benefits  would  accrue  to  the 
population at large. 
 
10.  In  collaboration  with  WHO,  ADB  organized  a  regional  workshop  on  public–private 
collaboration on regional health security in July 2010 in Shanghai. Participants included senior 
representatives of multinational enterprises working in Asia and the Pacific. The objective of the 
workshop  was  to  explore  private  sector  interest  in  establishing  a  PPP  for  regional  health 
security  to  facilitate  dialogue,  share  information  and  experience  at  the  regional  level,  and 
mobilize private sector resources to strengthen surveillance, early warning systems, and the 
response capacity of national health systems to health threats. Private sector participants in the 
workshop expressed interest in this initiative, but requested a detailed needs assessment and 
gap analysis from WHO. Participants proposed organizing a follow-up regional workshop in 
Singapore. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcomes 
11.  The TA will help to improve the health of the populations of Asia and the Pacific. The 
objective of the observatory is to collect and disseminate health-related information and good 
practices that will help governments adopt new health policies and reforms based on evidence. 
Improved health systems will guarantee more effective delivery of, and more equitable access 
to, health services. Effective health systems must also be able to address emerging health 
threats and reinforce both national and regional health security.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.   The TA has two components: the main component will provide support to the Asia 
Pacific Health Observatory, the other will follow up on an ADB–WHO initiative to involve the 
private sector in a PPP for regional heath security. 
 
13.  The  observatory,  developed  on  the  model  of  the  European  Observatory  on  Health 
Systems  and  Policies,  will  involve  governments,  development  partners,  and  the  research 
community  to  generate  and  disseminate  health-related  information  on  health  systems  and 
priority policy issues for the region. By allocating $300,000 for the activities of the observatory,7 
ADB will become a member of the steering committee, thereby participating in the decision-
making  process  and  helping  to  define  the  priority  health  issues  to  be  addressed  by  the 
observatory and the observatory’s work program for the next 3 years. As a member of the 
steering committee, ADB will be able to raise issues that it considers important, and to decide, 
in consultation with the other members of the steering committee, how the ADB contribution will 
be used. Most of the TA resources will be used to finance (i) studies describing national health 
systems in the region (descriptions of health systems in transition) and analysis addressing 
common health policy issues (policy briefs); and (ii) conferences and workshops to disseminate 
study results and promote regional and cross-sector coordination and collaboration.  
 
14.  ADB will also take advantage of the contacts that it established with the private sector in 
Asia in June 2010 in Shanghai to explore how the private sector can participate in the dialogue 
among the various stakeholders interested in improving the functioning of health systems and 
                                                 
7  This will cover the cost of surveys and studies (estimated at $260,000), administrative costs (estimated at $10,000) 
and contingencies (estimated at $30,000). See Appendix 2.

4   
addressing priority health issues in the region effectively. The ADB and WHO PPP initiative 
focuses on regional health security, which has the potential to benefit all parties. For the private 
sector, it would be an opportunity to express its concerns related to health in the region with the 
members of the steering committee of the observatory. A PPP could assist in addressing the 
findings and recommendations of the various studies generated by the observatory. 
 
15.  In collaboration with WHO, the TA will fund a regional conference in Singapore to follow-
up on the establishment of a PPP for regional health security. Participants will discuss the 
institutional  arrangements  for  a  PPP,  and  identify  resource  mobilization  mechanisms.  The 
private sector will help organize the Singapore conference. ADB will allocate up to $200,000 for 
the conference to cover (i) the engagement of a public relations consultant for 2 person-months, 
(ii) the engagement of one or two workshop facilitators for up to 7 person-days in total, (iii) 
support for travel and accommodation of government representatives. The remaining funds 
(from the maximum amount of $200,000 allocated for the workshop) will be allocated to support 
activities of the observatory.  
 
16.  In line with the priorities of the ADB operational plan for health under Strategy 2020,8 this 
regional  TA  supports  governance  in  the  health  sector  and  regional  public  goods,  through 
partnerships and through generation and dissemination of knowledge products. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-other sources) for a total amount of $500,000. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency. For the observatory, WHO—as secretariat of the 
observatory—will be the implementing agency. A TA agreement will be signed between ADB 
and WHO for the implementation of the TA activities related to the observatory. ADB’s Poverty 
Reduction,  Gender,  and  Social  Development  Division  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Department will be the TA supervising unit. A representative from the TA supervising unit will 
act as ADB’s member of the steering committee, and will oversee the implementation of the TA 
activities, including oversight of the implementation agreement with WHO.  
 
19.  The  TA  supervising  unit  will  be  directly  responsible  for  activities  related  to  the 
organization of the regional conference in Singapore to discuss public–private partnership for 
regional health security. The organization of this conference will be coordinated with WHO and 
representatives of the private sector in Singapore. 
 
20.  Procurement  of  goods  and  services  for  both  the  observatory  and  the  Singapore 
conference will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from time to time) and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  Disbursement  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time), possibly using the advance payment and the 
statement of expenditure procedures. 
 
21.  The TA will start in February 2011 and is expected to be completed by 31 December 
2014.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asia Pacific Health Observatory, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Asia Pacific Health Observatory 
 
1.  Background 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB), in collaboration with the World Health Organization 
(WHO) and the World Bank, is proposing the establishment of an Asia Pacific Health Observatory 
in collaboration with regional research institutions and government representatives. Resources will 
be mobilized from the observatory’s partners. Individual consultants or consulting firms will be 
recruited by ADB, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time), to implement studies and surveys.  
 
2.  Objective and Scope of Assignment 
 
2.  The objective of the assignment is to implement studies and surveys on policy issues and 
on national health systems. Details of the proposed studies and surveys will be determined in 
consultation with the observatory, which will be established in the first quarter of 2011. 
 
B.  Regional Health Security Initiative: Singapore Workshop 
 
1.  Background 
 
3.  ADB,  in  collaboration  with  WHO,  will  organize  a  workshop  with  the  private  sector  to 
mobilize public–private partnerships aimed at strengthening regional health security for the benefit 
of ADB developing member countries.  The event will bring together key stakeholders from the 
private sector, governments, and development agencies to identify opportunities for collaboration.   
 
4.  ADB will engage a public relations specialist and a facilitator to assist in the preparation, 
conduct, monitoring and evaluation of the conference.  
 
2.  Objective and Scope of Assignment 
 
5.  The objective of the assignment is to organize and conduct a high level regional conference 
on health security. The consultants will be responsible for managing the conference and will work 
closely with ADB and WHO to ensure a focused and high quality discussion.  
 
3.  Detailed Tasks 
 
    a.  Public Relations Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant will be responsible for preparing all the requirements for the effective and 
efficient  conduct  of  the  conference  in  coordination  with  ADB  and  WHO.  Under  the  direct 
supervision of ADB, the consultant will be responsible for the following tasks:  
 
(i)  prepare and plan for public–private sector participation at the conference, including 
the selection of additional potential private sector partners for health security; 
(ii)  identify resource persons and qualified speakers for the conference;  
(iii)  update the database of private companies relevant to the regional health security 
agenda;

(iv)  coordinate specific information for public–private sector participants, and liaise with 
public and private sector participants, ADB, and WHO officials, as appropriate; 
(v)  plan  and  develop  advocacy  materials  and  liaise  with  the  event  organizer  for 
production and printing; 
(vi)  manage public–private sector relations prior, during, and after the conference; 
(vii)  organize  an  advocacy  visit  by  ADB  officials  to  promote  the  event  among 
government officials and heads of private companies; 
(viii)  assist ADB in finalizing presentations for the conference; 
(ix)  assist ADB media relations specialists by providing inputs for press releases; and  
(x)  produce a report on public–private sector participation at the conference, and follow 
up on agreed actions between ADB and public–private sector representatives at the 
conference. 
 
7.  The  consultant  will  be  engaged  for  2  person-months.  The  consultant  should  have 
experience in public relations, and a good track record in organizing international conferences with 
at least 100 participants, with high-level delegation particularly from Asia and the Pacific, and 
should have a significant network in the private sector. 
 
b.  Facilitator(s) 
 
8.  The consultant(s) will coordinate and facilitate information exchange, sharing of experience, 
good  practices  and  identification  of  synergies  among  public–private  participants  during  the 
conference. The consultant will follow guidance from ADB and WHO in moderating the discussion 
and flow of information. 
 
9.  The consultant(s) will be engaged for a maximum of 7 person-days in total. He or she 
should have experience in high-level, international conferences, and should be neutral, gender and 
culture sensitive, and have excellent communication skills.
